Original Sample: “Unicorns.” Berm grumbled, slipping off his hefty gloves made from troll hides. “Why unicorns?” His hand raked across his rough face then he thrust open the iron gate leading from the main market cavern to the livestock pens. The usual stench was masked by the critters inside but didn't fool Berm. Normally it was a pungent mix of sweat, manure and hay but today the unicorns’ scent of rain and flowers filled the air, an abomination in this grimy pit. The unicorns, paradisiacal creatures in a lowly dungeon, their fragrance made him clench the leather handle of his squat club hanging by his side—a necessity for defending against gory encounters with sharp horns. Berm wasn’t easily rattled, yet tales of men skewered by unicorns kept him wary. Stumbling deeper into dim pens, unicorns appeared, their tall stature matching his own. Their eerie stillness unnerved many hunters but not Berm. The unicorns’ gaze was disquieting to others, but Berm had no qualms staring back as he executed his grim duty—probably saved his skin more than once. Flash? A glint caught his eye from a unicorn, he pivoted. A blade, initially aimed at his neck, grazed his shoulder's thick leather, and the assailant lurched into the pen. The unicorns remained statuesque. Berm whirled, club unclasped and struck apart another lunge. The knife zinged wide; Berm advanced, slamming his fist into the attacker’s chest prompting a gasp-turned-groan as they collapsed. No respite, Berm’s club crushed down breaking the attacker’s forearm, a scream escaping before limpness took over. Lightweight. Berm muttered, nudging with a foot. He knelt, yanking the mask from his attacker, revealing a forest nymph. How had it navigated the market let alone found Melk’s stall? Another nudge, the nymph stirred. The club ended the question, blood spattering as the nymph’s skull gave way. Tugging the lifeless form by an ankle, Berm dragged the remains outside the pen, hollering into the market. “Melk! Pest in yer pens. Clean it up while I work!” Berm left the twitching corpse at the doorway, facing the unicorns again who sensed their fate, shuffling agitatedly. They knew what followed. Berm grinned, not minding when fear glazed their noble selves—they lent the job intrigue. Melk appeared, wide-eyed at the sight of carnage. “Mind yer step.” Berm advised. “Blood.”
